# Additional Topics

## Voronoi Tesselations (definition)

- Consider $n$ points $x_{1}, \ldots x_{n}$ in space $\mathbb{X}$
- Let $d(\cdot, \cdot)$ be distance metric on $\mathbb{X}$
- For each $i = 1, \ldots, n$ define $\mathcal{X}_{i}$ as
$$
\mathcal{X}_{i} = \left\{x \in \mathbb{X}: d(x, x_{i}) \leq d(x, x_{j}) \text{ for all } j \neq i\right\}
$$
- $\mathcal{X}_{i}$: all points in $\mathbb{X}$ **closer** to $x_{i}$ than to any other $x_{j}$

## Voroni Tesselation (example)

- Can compute using [**deldir**](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/deldir/index.html) package in R

```{r}
#| label: example-voronoi
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-height: 5
#| fig-align: center
library(deldir)
set.seed(42)
x <- runif(20)
y <- runif(20)
dxy <- deldir(x,y,rw=c(0,1,0,1))
cxy1 <- cvt(dxy,verb=FALSE)
plot(cxy1$tiles)
with(cxy1$centroids,points(x,y,pch=16))
```

## Bezier Curves (definition)

- Given $D+1$ control points $\boldsymbol{b}_{0}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{b}_{D}$ in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$
- Degree $D$ Bezier curve is
$$
\boldsymbol{x}(t) = \sum_{d = 0}^{D}{\binom{D}{d}t^{d}(1-t)^{D-d}\boldsymbol{b}_{d}}.
$$
-  $\boldsymbol{x}(0) = \boldsymbol{b}_{0}$ and $\boldsymbol{x}(1) = \boldsymbol{b}_{D}$
- Used widely in computer graphics

## Bezier Curve Example 1

```{r}
#| label: fig-bezier-example1
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap: Quadratic Bezier curve example
controls <- data.frame(x = c(1, 4, 10), y = c(1, 10, 7))
t <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.001)

x <- (1-t)^2 * controls$x[1] + 2 * t*(1-t) * controls$x[2] + t^2 * controls$x[3] 
y <- (1-t)^2 * controls$y[1] + 2 * t*(1-t) * controls$y[2] + t^2 *controls$y[3] 

oi_colors <- palette.colors(palette = "Okabe-Ito")
par(mar = c(3,3,2,1), mgp = c(1.8, 0.5, 0))
plot(1, type = "n", xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0,10), xlab = "x", ylab = "y")
points(controls, pch = 16, cex = 1, col = oi_colors[9])
lines(x,y)
```

## Bezier Curve Example 2

```{r}
#| label: fig-bezier-example2
#| eval: true
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap: Quadratic Bezier curve example

par(mar = c(3,3,2,1), mgp = c(1.8, 0.5, 0))
plot(1, type = "n", xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0,10), xlab = "x", ylab = "y")
points(controls, pch = 16, cex = 1, col = oi_colors[9])
lines(x,y, col = oi_colors[3])


t_ix <- which(t == 0.3)

x01 <- (1 - t)*controls$x[1] + t * controls$x[2]
y01 <- (1 - t)*controls$y[1] + t * controls$y[2]

x12 <- (1 - t)*controls$x[2] + t * controls$x[3]
y12 <- (1-t)*controls$y[2] + t * controls$y[3]


lines(x01, y01, col = oi_colors[9])
lines(x12, y12, col = oi_colors[9])



points(x01[t_ix], y01[t_ix], col =  oi_colors[4], pch = 16)
points(x12[t_ix], y12[t_ix], col = oi_colors[4], pch = 16)
lines(x = c(x01[t_ix], x12[t_ix]), y = c(y01[t_ix], y12[t_ix]), col = oi_colors[4])
points(x[t_ix], y[t_ix], pch = 16, col = oi_colors[3])

t2_ix <- which(t == 0.5)
points(x01[t2_ix], y01[t2_ix], col =  oi_colors[8], pch = 16)
points(x12[t2_ix], y12[t2_ix], col = oi_colors[8], pch = 16)
lines(x = c(x01[t2_ix], x12[t2_ix]), y = c(y01[t2_ix], y12[t2_ix]), col = oi_colors[8])
points(x[t2_ix], y[t2_ix], pch = 16, col = oi_colors[3])
```
